 "So, just what type of alternatives are in use today? The most common type of alternative methods are: in-vitro tests, computer software, databases of tests already done (to avoid duplication), and even human "clinical trial" tests. Use of animal cells, organs, or tissue cultures is also deemed an alternative although, obviously, animal lives are sacrificed for the use of their parts. The specific tests are:
 
 
 
 Eytex
 Produced by the National Testing Corp. in Palm Springs, California, Eytex is an in-vitro (test-tube) procedure that measures eye irritancy via a protein alteration system. A vegetable protein from the jack bean mimics the reaction of the cornea to an alien substance. This alternative is used by Avon instead of the cruel Draize eye irritancy test.
 
 
 
 Skintex
 An in-vitro method to assess skin irritancy that uses pumpkin rind to mimic the reaction of a foreign substance on human skin (both Eytex and Skintex can measure 5,000 different materials).
 
 
 
 EpiPack
 Produced by Clonetics in San Diego, California, the EpiPack uses cloned human tissue to test potentially harmful substances.
 
 
 
 Neutral Red Bioassay
 Developed at Rockefeller University and promoted by Clonetics, the Neutral Red Bioassay is cultured human cells that are used to compute the absorption of a water-soluble dye to measure relative toxicity.
 
 
 
 Testskin
 Produced by Organogenesis in Cambridge, Massachusetts, Testskin uses human skin grown in a sterile plastic bag and can be used for measuring irritancy, etc. (this method is used by Avon, Amway, and Estee Lauder).
 
 
 
 TOPKAT
 Produced by Health Design, Inc. in Rochester, New York, TOPKAT is a computer software program that measures toxicity, mutagenicity, carcinogenicity, and teratonogenicity (this method is used by the U.S. Army, the Environmental Protection Agency, and the Food and Drug Administration).
 
 
 
 Ames Test
 Tests for carcinogenicity by mixing a test culture with Salmonella typhimurium and adding activating enzymes. It was able to detect 156 out of 174 (90%) animal carcinogens and 90 out of 100 (88%) non-carcinogenes.
 
 
 
 Agarose Diffusion Method
 Tests for toxicity of plastic and synthetic devices used in medical devices such as heart valves, artificial joints, and intravenous lines. Human cells and the test material are placed in a flask and are separated by a thin-layer of agarose (a derivative of seaweed agar). If the material tested is an irritant, an area of killed cells appears around the substance.
 
 
 
 Today, in-vitro (meaning, literally, "in glass") as opposed to in-vivo (meaning "whole animal") has flourished because of advances in tissue culture techniques and other analytical methods."

 I think it's true to say that there is a lot of testing by private companies on animals that just isn't necessary. A lot of people would agree this probably shouldn't be done, and I think I take that position. 
 
 On the other hand, there is also a lot of of public research done on animals as well. Public research, here, refers to researches funded by the US government -- NIH, NSF, etc (or government of other countries, although I know less about those). These follow strict animal usage guidelines, but regardless, they do require a lot of animals. 
 
 Just to name some specific examples, on the order of thousands (this is my guess, so I don't know what the numbers are, but I think these are reasonable numbers) of cats and monkeys die for neurophysiology research per year. The number of rhesus monkeys that die for AIDS research per year is probably much higher now because there is a large impetus for the government to pour money into AIDS research.
 
 Among other things, public research using animals should consider two principles:
 1. is the experiment necessary? (i.e. is the data already available, and is the result important to the general scientific understand of something)
 2. will the animal be in pain? aside from some pain related researches, all animals should be anesthetized (or locally anesthetized).
 
 I think that a more important question to ask is: what do we do about this sort of pubic animal research?
 
 This is a more important question because, after all, the researches are funded by your tax money, so you are, in some sense, responsible. Furthermore, I think that a lot of people would agree that just picking a squirrel down the street and beating on it for fun is just not a nice thing to do -- and probably similarly for privatized research of the type you mentioned.
 
 So what about public research? Should it be eliminated?

 I agree with you for the most part. The hard part about it is that there is some medical research, drug research for example, that cannot be done on tissue samples in a test tube. Drug research involves not only observing the effect of the drug on the target tissue or target cells, but observing the effect on all tissue and systems of the body. It is important to understand that drugs effect ALL tissues in the body (unless entry is prevented as in the blood brain barrier). Say for example: Morphine. Morphine is a narcotic pain reliever. It works by binding to the opiate receptor sites in the central nervous system. Well that's all well and good, but why can't I give it to someone with a really low blood pressure? Well, because it causes relaxation of vascular smooth muscle thereby decreasing systemic vascular resistence and increasing venous capitance, at the same time it is allowing the heart to slow and relax, decreasing total cardiac output by means of stroke volume and rate. This is just the effect on the cardiovascular system. Imagine all the other things it does in the body. Things like this are important to discover prior to using the drug on an unsuspecting patient in an emergency. So yes, I agree that if at all possible, and the results are the same or better, use testing that does not kill animals. But, people need to realize that there are many types of testing, and many of them must be done on living organisms with the same relative organ structure as humans (this is why we can't use grasshoppers).

 Today, in-vitro (meaning, literally, "in glass") as opposed to in-vivo (meaning "whole animal") has flourished because of advances in tissue culture techniques and other analytical methods."
 
 - taken from Animals and Alternatives in Testing - History, Science, and Ethics (sorry, i was too lazy to summarize)
